title: How to Construct a Hex Board

steps.headline: Decide how large your hexagons will be and plan your space.
steps.description: Hex is most frequently played on an 11 x 11 board, but any size can be used. According to John Nash, co-inventor of the game, 14 x 14 is an optimum size. For however many spaces N you want a side to be, plan the space to be 1.5N units wide. That is, if you want a 14 x 14 board with one-inch spaces, choose a surface at least 21 inches (53.3 cm) wide.

steps.headline: Working lightly in pencil, draw horizontal and vertical lines through the center of your page.
Draw a circle centered at the intersection of these lines.
Draw a set of circles, each centered on the intersection of the last circle with the vertical line.
steps.description: This article describes the basic pattern. Extend it as far as you wish.

steps.headline: Draw angled lines through the points where the circles intersect, marked in red.
Create the whole set of these lines.
Then draw the angled lines going the other way.
Draw vertical lines through the intersections of the angled lines, marked in red.
Starting at the center, ink, etch, or otherwise make permanent and prominent the pattern of hexagons you want.
steps.description: You are aiming for a rhombus such as the one above, with the same number of hexagons on each side.

steps.headline: Erase the construction lines, leaving the rhombus of hexagons.
Color opposite sides of the rhombus as shown.
Learn how to play hex, and enjoy.

text: Decide how large your hexagons will be and plan your space. Hex is most frequently played on an 11 x 11 board, but any size can be used. According to John Nash, co-inventor of the game, 14 x 14 is an optimum size. For however many spaces N you want a side to be, plan the space to be 1.5N units wide. That is, if you want a 14 x 14 board with one-inch spaces, choose a surface at least 21 inches (53.3 cm) wide. Working lightly in pencil, draw horizontal and vertical lines through the center of your page.  Draw a circle centered at the intersection of these lines.  Draw a set of circles, each centered on the intersection of the last circle with the vertical line. This article describes the basic pattern. Extend it as far as you wish. Draw angled lines through the points where the circles intersect, marked in red.  Create the whole set of these lines.  Then draw the angled lines going the other way.  Extend that set, too.  Draw vertical lines through the intersections of the angled lines, marked in red.  Create that set of lines.  Starting at the center, ink, etch, or otherwise make permanent and prominent the pattern of hexagons you want. You are aiming for a rhombus such as the one above, with the same number of hexagons on each side. Erase the construction lines, leaving the rhombus of hexagons.  Color opposite sides of the rhombus as shown.  Learn how to play hex, and enjoy.
